ChristyWrites
I’m a Northern California-based writer seeking redemption through explorations of family, relationships, food, and memory.
Apr 5

Imagine

I titled this piece “Imagine” because that’s the name of the house I walked by today. There it was, proudly worn in block letters across the puffed chest of a staunch brown shingle house on the hill. “Imagine.” The letters were multi-colored. Deeply colored. Immediately, John Lennon’s voice filled my head (how could it not?), where it’s remained ever since. The house reminded me of a little Swiss chalet clinging to a mountainside, but really it was a brown shingle in urban Oakland, not far from downtown.

It was up the hill from Casa Monet and another house named for a famous painter, whimsical structures painted unusual colors with bold name tags. One of them was for sale. Curious, I crossed the street, peered into the little plastic realtor’s box of flyers and saw that the structure is listed at over $1.3M (that’s million) dollars. In Oakland. Up from Grand Avenue.

Yes, Oakland is hot. Oakland is finally having her moment, after decades of attempts at this very thing, and it’s a little scary. It’s gentrification big time, of course, and of course that is troubling. I have to admit I find it exciting that gorgeous, crumbling Victorian mansions are getting a little love before they’re unsave-able. I have to admit I find it exciting that whole areas of our city are opening up to potential investment, that swaths of the city are becoming safer, that I feel I can walk more places… but I feel a little guilty, a little stricken. I’m “white.” My striding presence may not be welcome in some of these pockets.

When I encountered the “Imagine” house, though, I was near-done with my jaunt. I had parked at my dad’s old “independent living” facility, Grand Lake Gardens, picked up his mail, deposited it in my car, locked the car, and then struck out over the hill in the direction of Piedmont Avenue, Pill Hill, and the hospital, where my dad languishes. I hope he’s not languishing. But, truthfully, that’s the word that came to mind.

Before I did so, though, I popped into Grand Lake Gardens to pick up my dad’s mail from Kathy. Sassy, gorgeous, and together Kathy. She wore strappy black sandals with chunky silver heels. She always looks great — polished, pulled together, warm, and bright. She searched in the storage closet for my dad’s mail, making a special effort to find it all. We chatted. I asked how Jody was.

“Jody’s cat died today. She’s probably having a hard time.”

I went upstairs to see Jody.

I almost didn’t remember what floor my dad and Jody had been on. I hazarded a guess and was right. Before turning right down the hall to Jody’s apartment, though, I decided to stop at my dad’s.

I wanted to peer in again, to remember for a moment when he was a little more able.

I was in luck. The room was being cleaned so I could actually see right in and not just gaze forlornly at the closed door.

Sutka was in there. A woman from — I’m afraid I don’t remember. She is from Eastern Europe, that I am sure of, but I don’t recall if it’s Poland, Czech Republic… or where. I feel sorry about that. I should remember. She bothered to tell me, I made like I cared… I should have remembered. I did a quick Google search. It came up as a Romany name, which is of course interesting.

Anyway, Sutka was there vacuuming. When she saw me, she stopped the machine. She had blue plastic gloves on. She said, “I would hug you, but…” I said, “I will hug you!” She came forward. We hugged. She kept her blue gloves off of me and hugged me with her arms.

“How are you? How is your father?” she cried. “I miss him, your father! I cry here sometimes! I have cried here, remembering him! A very sweet man, your father, a special man, a good man,” she said.

I told her my father is in the hospital with severe sepsis, that I’m hoping he’s out soon.

“How is he at Piedmont Gardens?” (the sister facility to Grand Lake Gardens, where you go when you can’t live “independently” anymore).

“Mmm… I’m not sure,” I said.

Her face fell. The she looked both ways and rubbed her forefingers and thumb together, indicating, “expensive.”

I lowered my voice. “I know,” I said.

“You maybe can get a nurse for him,” she said. “Much less.”

I hesitated.

“I know,” I said. “I know. I think about it all the time. But it’s not clear that I can afford it. It’s very confusing.”

What I of course didn’t explain is that my father paid $50,000 up front so that if he runs out of money they will still take care of him. It’s a kind of insurance. A kind of deal with the devil. The thing is, the thing we didn’t think about is, if we choose this option, they will make absolutely sure they take all of his money. And they have.

“Tell your father I miss him,” she said. I promised I would.

Then, I went down the hall, turned left, and made my way to the other side of the building to Jody’s. Jody was my dad’s friend from the time my mom died when I was 26 to the time he fell down in her kitchen and cut his head open something awful. He was on way too many blood pressure medications at that time, completely over-medicated, and was fainting from extremely low blood pressure. When he went into the hospital for dozens of stitches, Jody crossed her arms and said he couldn’t come back.

At the time, I was mad about this. I found it exceedingly cold. Now, I understand better. My father already had early dementia and was not altogether there. Jody said today, “I know you were sore at me about that, but those stairs… I couldn’t have him going down those stairs…” I understood. I assured her of this.

She didn’t answer her door at first when I knocked.

“Come in!” she said.

I tried the doorknob, which remained fixed in position.

“It’s locked,” I called.

“Come in!” she said again.

I tried the doorknob again in case I’d been mistaken.

“Jody, it’s locked.”

After a couple of minutes, the door opened.

Jody looked happy to see me. She is bent over now. She has been for some time. But her blue eyes are still bright and playful, and, as I quickly learned, her laugh is still youthful and total, shaking her whole body.

“I heard your cat died today,” I ventured.

“Yes. That’s really hard,” she offered.

She looked down. After some time, she said, “You know, when I came out of the shower, I’d sit on the bed, and she’d lick the water off my back.”

I was thunderstruck. And moved.

“She was a good cat. She was eighteen-and-a-half, really old. She had a stroke. She came out of the bedroom, and she couldn’t walk. Her head was in this weird position, and she was blind in one eye.”

She said she couldn’t take her cat to the vet. She said there was no way to get there, no one to drive her.

“Why didn’t you call me?” I asked. “You can always call me, you know.”

“Oh,” she said. She picked up her address book and made sure she had my number in a place she could easily find.

“Robby was good though,” she said. Robby is her son, a couple of years younger than me. “He cleaned up her cat box and took the cat food… he did the dishes. He was really good.”

“It makes you think though. What if I have a stroke. What will my kids do? I don’t want to be like that… I don’t know what my kids would do…”

After some time, I took my leave. Jody was amazed I was going to walk over the hill to the hospital, where my dad is. To her, it seemed like a long way, and to be honest because I’m turning into a wimp, and because I drive far too much, it seemed far to me too… until I began.

I left my car on the street and struck out like a real pioneer up the hill. I found a good pace. I passed multiple outpourings of blooming wisteria, insanely, stupefyingly fragrant, impossibly beautiful.

I passed a redwood tree at one point festooned in ribbons of lavender wisteria. Everywhere in the city of Oakland today, wisteria was blooming in unison with itself. In patches, clinging to garden gates, draped around trees, climbing arbors of all kinds, mixing with yellow roses and jasmine, the wisteria was the theme of the day, more so even than the “Imagine” house, but maybe they are related. They were equally surprising and magical.

I made my way, then, over the hill. The air was soft. I wore my work skirt which quickly annoyed me so I rolled it up almost to my hipline so I could stride freely. I felt free and strong, realizing that Jody and my father could once upon a time also strike out, climb a hill, clamber down the other side, and basically go wherever they hell they wanted to go whenever the hell they wanted to go there. Ah, youth.

I’m not young anymore, God knows. I’ll be 49 (!) this month, but hell I can still scale a mountain, and I still feel stronger with every mile that passes. Thank God.

I wended my way to the hospital as water flows though the cracks of a decrepit roof, as the crow flies, as they say. Meaning, I didn’t walk as if I was driving. In fact, I assiduously avoided thoroughfares and traffic. Many, many times I found myself on streets I had never been on before, and, mind you, I’ve essentially lived in Oakland for 48+ years. So, that’s rather striking. And exciting.

I found my way through, slipping through cracks, down stairways, along footpaths that you simply can’t discern while driving. It’s like magic, really. I encountered majestic, singular, lonely redwoods with girths the size of carriage houses. Magical homes with diamond-shaped panes tucked into lanes where no street touches, where you must bring your groceries by hand, on foot, or not at all.

People of all kinds, stripes, colors, and situations talking, resting, passing. An overweight man and a disabled man seated on a cement wall chatting. Probably “poor,” both of them, but heck, how poor? They have time to sit on a wall, they have each other, they can sit in the sun. They can chat. They have nowhere to go in that moment. Who’s to say that’s not a kind of heaven, not a kind of wealth?

I passed a wide and wild stream banked by dark, mature redwoods in the most unlikely of places — behind what was formerly Auto Row. Who knew? Why did I not know this part of Oakland? I passed mansions, many of them, tucked away down side streets. Victorian mansions, brown-shingle mansions, craftsmen mansions.

I hankered after them all. I play little games, imaging myself here and there, imagining myself buying this house, no that one, imagining running a little boarding house or B&B. Or just noticing an especially comely little room with a prettily-paned window and imagining being safe in there, writing, reading, admiring the sun’s rays, the sound of the fronds of the redwood brushing against the pretty window, the air, the breeze, the silence. A pretty little aerie.

When I spot those, I imagine myself there. Front porches also get me. Some of them today had perfect rocking chairs on them. I see the love in these porches, in these gardens. I see the potted plants on the interior porch railing… I feel the love. I wonder about the occupants. I miss them. I want them. I want to be like them. I want to be home. To make my home more of a home. To feel safe.

Eventually, I found my way to the hospital. I came out onto it surprised. Right at the foot of it, emerging from a dark mini-forest to the bright pavement and asphalt and glancing light off cars and windshields. I pressed the button for the walk signal and practiced ballet steps while waiting for the light to turn and listening to rap from the car behind me.

I passed the yawning, trembling Chevrolet sign that is all that remains of the cavernous showroom that used to be there, that is now being built up for apartments and retail, no doubt. Auto Row was always ugly so maybe this will be okay… but the idea of chain stores and Starbucks on our Auto Row makes me sick with grief, truth be told. I hope I still recognize Oakland in five years.

I made my way up the final hill and into the reception of Summit Hospital. The same dapperly dressed front desk manager that’s always there was there again tonight. This time, he gave me a formal nod of recognition. (Last time, I noticed him noticing my high-heeled sandals. He liked them.) I greeted him and his acolyte, who made me a badge. There was a flicker of recognition in the acolyte’s eyes too. For some reason I held his gaze. Just to be open. To be friendly. To acknowledge.

These are the “invisible” people of the hospital, the people most of us just want to get by. It does feel like a little bit of an affront to be stopped and to have to sign in to see your loved one, but I realize it’s for safety reasons. For some reason on the other side of the hospital, when you come in that way, you have to go through a metal detector and have the guard check your backpack and purse. Last time, the rotund African guard said gruffly, “You have any weapons?” I laughed derisively (now I regret that) and said, “No. Of course not.”

But, of course, he has to ask me that. He can’t just ask people who look like they might. Right? That’s called profiling. He’s right to ask me. I’m wrong to be offended. And even wronger to show it.

I made my way upstairs. After walking all that way, slipping like water through Oakland’s streets and byways, I felt like a million bucks. I felt strong, even a little sexy, which I don’t feel very often anymore truth be told. So, that was fun.

I was confident approaching my dad’s room because I’d called earlier. A Dr. Ramirez told me my dad was good and might be discharged today. He was a little testy when I asked what happened to Dr. Chen and why did my dad have so many different doctors, and how could there be continuity of care this way? But, still, I was happy and excited to see him.

Which is why I was surprised when I entered the room and he looked not just asleep but totally out of it, with that furrowed brow again that so worried and concerned me in the emergency room last Tuesday night. This is not “sleeping.” At least it doesn’t appear so to me. It looks like sleeping in pain.

Earlier today, Dr. Ramirez went on about chocking hazards and how my dad has dementia (as if I don’t know) and how he might aspirate and how he’s coughing and maybe food when into the lung and how he maybe can’t swallow…

I humored him.

My dad has never had a single problem eating. Eating is his favorite hobby. He eats like a vacuum cleaner. He loves all food, but especially brie cheese, prime rib, blue cheese, rum raisin ice cream, pineapple sherbet, and brussels sprouts. Oh, and oysters. He’s always had a very healthy appetite.

Anyway, my dad didn’t appear to be in good shape tonight. I was disappointed, flustered, aggrieved, and annoyed. The pretty but bland young nurse was there again. At least she’s nice. Her boyfriend studies chemistry at UC Santa Barbara. She’s innocuous. Blonde. Mascaraed. But, she’s okay. She didn’t flinch while suctioning phlegm from my father’s mouth. Well, maybe she did a little. Okay, she did. But I could tell she was trying not to. I give her points for that.

The African nurse I got annoyed with a few nights ago but who I’d made peace with and left bonded to was there too. She and I, after a rough beginning, had chosen to trust one another. When I entered the room last night, my father was flushed and coughing something awful. As I drew closer it seemed he had a rash, welts even, on his face. This alarmed me, as he’d been given a shitty, bad antibiotic he was allergic to on Tuesday and had erupted in an overall body rash that itched something awful. He had to be given intravenous antihistamines then. On the phone today, some nurse said something about morphine.

“Morphine?” I said, dully but with fury.

“Yes,” she hesitated. “But he hasn’t had any!”

“Oh, good.” I said, trying not to sound unduly icy. “I hope if someone wants to give him morphine, they will check with me first.”

“Yes, yes..” It’s unclear to me that they will.

The nurses and nurses’ assistants told me my father is staying up all night to watch TV and he sleeps all day as a result. When I got home later, I saw my neighbor Claudia. She immediately said, “Sleeping? Or in a stupor?”

Exactly. In a stupor, I think, is more like it. The question is, Why. Why would Dr. Ramirez (whoever that is. No doctor has yet introduced their self to me) say my father was going home today when this obviously wasn’t the case? Where was Dr. Chen? Why does each nurse I encounter say, “I didn’t have him yesterday, I don’t know,” whenever I asked if his condition has changed from the preceding day? It’s aggravating, I tell you. Disconcerting.

We agreed I could let him “sleep.” I left. I walked back to my car a different way. I cleaved closer to Piedmont Avenue this time and then set off over the hill. I wound up at the edge of the Oakland Rose Garden and found a cinnamon-colored footpath. I passed scads of wisteria, scenting the air to a frenzy. I passed billowing jasmine and clouds of tiny white and yellow roses emerging from the permanent gloaming of the mysterious redwoods.

At one point, I sat down in the path and breathed in the soft Spring scent of earth, grass, and flowers, and marveled that I was in the middle of Oakland and could hear not a shred of traffic, though it was rush hour. The redwoods absorbed everything. They were my friends.

I made my way out… and eventually back to my car, stopping for moment at the place where I wheeled my father’s wheelchair a few months ago. I had put on the brakes and sat beside his chair, under a benevolent, spreading tree that embraced us as a man played guitar on a balcony above us.

Eventually he heard my father and me murmuring below and paused and sort of craned his neck. I called up, “I like hearing you play. I’m here with my father. Is it okay if we listen?” He was tickled and played with extra abandon. I could hear the flourishes he added. We were all secretly happy and tickled, yet never saw one another’s faces.

That house? That house has been sold. The garden, the spreading tree, the sheltering plants and bushes are all gone. The new owners left two strong palm trees, thank God. They were smart to do so. They are amazing trees. The man with the guitar? I don’t know where he is now.
